message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Among the options, compression of the stellate ganglion can cause Horner syndrome, while the other options do not involve the sympathetic pathway that leads to Horner syndrome. The patient’s shoulder and arm pain are likely related to the same underlying cause.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic website for help. The patient’s symptoms and risk factors suggest that the most likely cause is compression of the stellate ganglion, which can lead to Horner’s syndrome - ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus or aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery would present with more severe symptoms, and infiltration of the cervical plexus is less common and would present with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which can be caused by compression of the stellate ganglion. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus is associated with multiple cranial nerve deficits. Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery is not associated with ptosis. Infiltration of the cervical plexus is not a common cause of Horner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which is caused by disruption of the sympathetic pathway that begins in the hypothalamus and terminates in the eye. The most common cause of Horner syndrome in adults is compression of the stellate ganglion, which can occur due to lung tumors or other masses in the upper chest. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus, aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery, and infiltration of the cervical plexus are less likely causes of these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which involves ptosis and miosis on the same side of the face as the lesion. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is compression of the stellate ganglion, which can be caused by lung cancer, Pancoast syndrome, or brachial plexus injury. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus is not likely to cause Horner syndrome, and aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery would cause symptoms on the opposite side of the body. Infiltration of the cervical plexus is not a common cause of Horner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of ptosis and unequal pupils suggests Horner syndrome, which can be caused by a compression of the stellate ganglion. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus and aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery would have more extensive neurological symptoms. Infiltration of the cervical plexus would cause shoulder and arm pain but not ophthalmologic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Horner’s syndrome, which results from a disruption of the sympathetic nerve pathways that supply the face and eyes. Among the options, only compression of the stellate ganglion can cause Horner’s syndrome, which can explain the patient's ptosis and unequal pupils. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus can cause a similar clinical presentation but is less likely given the patient’s symptoms of shoulder and arm pain. Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery and infiltration of the cervical plexus are not associated with Horner’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Horner's syndrome, which is caused by compression of the stellate ganglion. A thrombosis of the cavernous sinus would cause more extensive neurologic deficits, an aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery would not cause ptosis, and infiltration of the cervical plexus would not cause unequal pupils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Horner’s syndrome, which can result from compression of the stellate ganglion. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus would present with multiple cranial nerve palsies, while an aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery would present with visual symptoms. Infiltration of the cervical plexus is a less likely cause of these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which can be caused by compression of the stellate ganglion. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus can cause ophthalmologic symptoms, but it would not explain the ptosis or unequal pupils. Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery and infiltration of the cervical plexus are not associated with Horner syndrome.
